title: Signage Letters ID
content:
Greetings!

Wondering if I can get a second, or third set of eyes on these letters. I was thinking Benton Sans Bold or News Gothic but I'm just not 100% at the moment. Any thoughts would be much appreciated.

JB

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130629070114im_/http:/typophile.com/files/signage_6440.jpg)
author: Nachos

comments.content: Tough set of letters to ID... not very distinctive. Can we see a clearly view of the "R"?
Unfortunately this was the only photo that I was given by a client of mine. I agree and sorry that I don't have a better image.

I agree with Jeff, but in a way that's the good news. That also means it would be hard to say anything similar was not a match, based on those letters. The R has a straight leg. If it does not touch the stem, then you could use Franklin Gothic, for example. If the leg of the R does touch the stem, then you could use [AG Schoolbook Medium](http://web.archive.org/web/20130629070114/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/berthold/ag-schoolbook-bq/medium/?testdrive=custom%3D0%26dock%3Dfalse%26size%3D118%26w%3D720%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3DLONDOR%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3Dfit%26seed%3D40) (with some squooshing), or [Nobel Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20130629070114/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/fb-nobel/?testdrive=custom%3D0%26dock%3Dfalse%26size%3D118%26w%3D720%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3DLONDOR%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3Dfit%26seed%3D27) (with squooshed O), or [Praxis Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20130629070114/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/praxis/?testdrive=custom%3D0%26dock%3Dfalse%26size%3D118%26w%3D720%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3DLONDOR%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3Dfit%26seed%3D23), with a little O squooshing.

If you get any idea about a few other key letters, like M, G, S or C, you can use the beta version of the [Sans Serif ID Guide](http://web.archive.org/web/20130629070114/http:/www.bowfinprintworks.com/SansGuide/sanssearch.php) to locate other candidates. As I did in this answer.

- Mike Yanega

I'd also suggest Futura Bold Condensed, or any condensed mid-century geometric for that matter.

- Lex

That Futura weight is OK, but lighter weights don't have the flat topped N.

- Mike Yanega
